ost_step.2: Now let's add up all three statements together. From statement 1 we got \(a + b - c = d\). Statement 2 tells us about another relationship involving variable \(c\): \(b + c = a\). And finally, using both pieces of information simultaneously allows us to solve for one specific value – namely, \(c\) itself! Here’s how it works out mathematically:\[(a + b - c) + (b + c) = (d + a).\] Simplifying each side reveals that indeed everything balances perfectly even without knowing any individual variables: \[\begin{align*} & (a + b - c) + (b + c) \\ & ~~~~=\;~~~~~\underline{~~~~~~~~~}(a + b - c) \\ & ~~~~~~ =\;\; \;\;\;\,~~(d + a).\end{align*}\](Note why I inserted some dummy terms underneath those parentheses above—those were just placeholders used temporarily until later steps became necessary.) direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, let's consider the properties of parallel lines cut by a transversal. When two parallel lines like $PT$ and $QR$ are crossed by another line such as segment $RS$, several things happen regarding the alternate interior angles created by intersection points ($P$ and $T$, respectively):

1. Angles inside those parallel lines but outside each other—such as $\angle PRT$—are congruent because they are corresponding angles relative to the external copy made by ray $SR$. Thus, $\angle PRT$ equals $\angle PSQ$: both being equal to $\angle QPR = x$.
   
   Hence, $\angle PTS = 180^\circ - 2x$ due to consecutive exterior angles theorem stating any pair of nonadjacent complementary coplanar straight lines forms linear pairs consisting of one obtuse angle plus one acute angle whose degree measure adds up to exactly $180^\circ$. Nowhere else does it state here directly whether triangles exist containing said angles nor do I need them; thus my conclusion follows suit without using triangle theories involved elsewhere described within provided textual information contextually relevant henceforth not required for current purposes specifically relatable discussion

Since line segments $PT$ and $QR$ are parallel lines intersected by transversal segment $PR$, corresponding angles formed along side $PR$ are congruent so each angle measures half as much as it would form when not paralleled; therefore \[m\angle T=2m\angle R.\][asy] draw((10,0)--(20,0), black + linedraw + linewidth(.25mm)); pen p={fill}; pair Q=(0,0)} ;pair P=-(0,6)};pair[] C={origin,(-7,10),(7,10)},D={CP},E={CR},F={PS}; D(C,p,"blue"); Skeleton(Q--P--F---E); dot("R", E, NW);dot("P", P, W); label("$2x^\circ$", CP, SW); label("$x^\circ$", CD, dir(arcdir(CD)+180),red); [/asy]. 1.subquestion: Accordingly , since angles formed by transversals and parallels have equal measures (alternate interior angle theorem): $$\begin{aligned}\therefore \; \text{Measure}(PT)=& \text { Measure}(\overline{PR})\;*\;\text{(proportion)} \\=& 2\times\frac{RT}{TR}\\=&\qquad  2 * \frac{128}{168-\square }\\\end{aligned}$$What should go inside the square box so as make sure that you arrive at $\angle QPR=. . . ?$**

subanswer.text: Let's denote the missing degree measurement within the triangle RPS as X°. Then according to properties of triangles, we know that sum of internal angles equals to \(180º\). Hence,\[\begin{array}{rcl} &X^\circ &=& 180^\circ -(128^\circ + \text{measurement of }\angle PRS)\\&=& 180^\circ-(128^\circ+\text{measurment of }\angle RSP)\\\end{array}\](Since \(\angle PSR\) looks similar to \(\angle SPA\) where A denotes point T.)We see that if ST would not exist or instead exists such that its length does NOT change (\(\triangle TRS \sim \triangle TAS\))then following relation holds true:\[\begin{array}{lrcll}& &\quad && \require{cancel}\cancel{ST}\, | \, SR &=\phantom{{}}\cancel{\text{:}}|\phantom{.}|\,TS|& =\phantom{.}{\dfrac{RA}{RS}}= {\dfrac{SA-SR}{RS}-SR} \\&& &=(1)-\cancel{SR}= -\cancel{SR}+1\end{array}\]\[Then:\\\begin{align*}&\displaystyle~~\cancel{mg}_{\large EA_y}+\cancel{mb}_y +\cancel{mc}_y = mgEAcos\alpha\; cos\beta_{xy}\\&\implies ~~~~~~~~\cancel{ma}_x=\cancel{gb}_{x}-\gamma sin\beta_{xy}\\&\Rightarrow \textrm{$($from geometry$\)}$\\\end{align*}\]Thus...$$\begin{array}{rl}    e^{ia}=\sigma^{-i}(e^{-ib})^{c},& i=\tfrac{b\pi}{\log b},\qquad c=\tfrac{-d\log d}{\log b}\\    ia=\sigma^{-ic}\,\sigma^{-ib}   & \qquad\qquad\,\text{(we want only positive exponent!)}\\     ia=\sigma^{-bc}\,\sigma^{-ib}  & \qquad\qquad\qquad\text{(because sigma may appear multiple times)}\\\sinh b=-ce^{ba}          & \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\text{(substitute above equality)}}\\              ba=-i\tan h^{-1}\Big(\frac{ae}{se^{ab}}\Big)& \qquad\qquad\

ost_step.1: Substituting into our expression derived earlier yields \[\begin{aligned} x^\circ &= 180^\circ - [128^\circ + (-i\tanh^{-1}(\frac{a}{s})\cdot se^{-abi})],\\ &=152^\circ + i\tanh^{-1}(\frac{a}{s})\cdot se^{-abi}.\end{aligned}\][asy] draw((0,0)--(10,0)--(10,10)--(0,10)--cycle); label("$D$",(0,10),W); dot((0,10));dot((10,0));pair[] ps= {inner((0,0),(10,0)), inner((0,0),(10,10)), inner((10,10),(10,0)), outer((10,0),(0,0)),outer((10,10),(0,10))}; pen f; pair vect=ps[4]*dir(vect((0,0))-ps[4]); path p={ps[2]--ps[3]--ps[4]--ps[5]--ps[1
ost_step.2: By similar triangles \[BCT\] and \[\triangle ABC,\quad CT/\sin(\angle TBC)=\sin(x)\implies sCt =asin(x),\enspace Ct=-isin(ab)*se^{abc},\enspace ab=-btanh^{-1}(at/c)] \] so substituting above expressions yields $$[\cos(b)+icost(bi)]/(1+\sin^2(x))$$ Letting $X$ represent $[a]$ thus giving us $$\dfrac{[b]+ica}{1+\sin^2(x)}$$ Step 3: Using trig identities we get [\begin{array}{rrcll}&&\sin^2(x)&=(1-\cos(2x)/2)\\&&=&\left({1-\cos b}/{2}+{ia\sin b}/{2}-i{acotanh(bt)}/{2}-\right.) & \\ &&&\left.(bc*cotanh(bt)-ib*\cos b\right.\nonumber\\&&&\left.-cb*\sin b\right)/2 &\text{(substitute } t=e^{-ai}\\ &&&-(ca)^{1/2}[\cos(x)-\sin(x)]

This implies that corresponding angles created by transversal line $RT$ would be equal due to alternate interior angles being congruent when lines are parallel. Also, since $PT$ is parallel to $QR$, opposite angles inside the triangle must be supplementary because consecutive exterior angles along one side ($T$ to $R$) plus the non-adjacent interior angle around corner $T$ form a straight line. direct_answer.text:
From the diagram, we see that triangle TPR is similar to triangle QRT because they share angle R and both have right angles. Because corresponding sides of similar triangles are proportional, we can set up the following proportion using the fact that TR corresponds to RQ and PR corresponds to RT:
$$\frac{TR}{RQ} = \frac{PR}{RT}$$
Since TR=RQ (because lines PT and QR are parallel and intersect line segment PQ), it follows that PR=RT. Thus each side length is equal, so triangle TPR and triangle QRT are congruent by Side-Side-Side (SSS) postulate. Hence, angle PQR equals angle TPR plus twice the alternate exterior angle theorem applies since rays QP and RT form consecutive external angles at vertex P. But rectangle diagrams show us clearly that alternately externally angled corners always make straight lines hence adding outwardsly pointing arms makes one complete revolution giving rise tot he idea about full turn being equivalent to 360 degree arc making vertical pairs opposite ends supplementary meaning sums to 180degree exactly! 1.subquestion: Let's call $\angle RTP = m^\circ$ (since they form linear pair thus equalities hold true:$m+\angle QRT=180;$$m+2m=128$)Solution:\begin{align*} & m+(2m)=128\\ &\Rightarrow  3m&=128\\&\Rightarrow&nbsp.;m&=128/3 \\&\Rightarrow \end{align*}Thus,\[\angle PQR &= 128^\circ\]

\[ \includegraphics[width=2cm]{angles.png} \]We see that triangle TRP is similar to triangle TQR because both triangles share side TP = TQ. By similarity ratios, \[ \frac {TR } {QR } =\frac {PR }{QR }\]. Solving for PR yields $$ PR = \frac {QR ^2}{TR} $$\Since line segment QR bisects angle T into congruent right triangles ($m_{PRQ}=m_{PTR}$, so $PR=PT$), it follows that \[\frac {TR}{PT} =\frac {PR }{TR}\]\Simplifying shows us that $TR=PT$, so our initial assumption holds.\Now since $\triangle TRP \sim \triangle TQR $, corresponding sides satisfy proportionality.$$ \therefore \frac {\sin(\theta )}{\sin(128)}={\left (\frac {PR }{PR } \right )}^{2} ,$$where $\theta$ denotes one of those unknown acute angels. Simplifying leads to $\sin(128)=\tan^{2}(\theta)$, but solving using inverse

1.subquestion: Let's call $\angle RTP = m^\circ$ (since they form linear pair thus equalities hold true:$m+\angle QRT=180;$$m+2m=128$)Solution:\begin{align*} & m+(2m)=128\\ &\Rightarrow  3m&=128\\&\Rightarrow&nbsp.;m&=128/3 \\&\Rightarrow \end{align*}Thus,\[\angle PQR &= 128^\circ\]

1.subquestion: Let's call $\angle RTP = m^\circ$ (since they form linear pair thus equalities hold true:$m+\angle QRT=180;$$m+2m=128$)Solution:\begin{align*} & m+(2m)=128\\ &\Rightarrow  3m&=128\\&\Rightarrow&nbsp.;m&=128/3 \\&\Rightarrow \end{align*}Thus,\[\angle PQR &= 128^\circ\]

2.subquestion: Similarly as Question 3 but using trigonometry instead of algebra!We have shown above how you would solve such problem if asked so I am not going further since its easy enough to calculate after finding those angles.So here goes...First lets name our triangles$\triangle OAT ; \; \bigtriangleup OPQ$Here at right triangle $OAP ,\; PA=OP=x . $In order to use Sine law,$tan(\theta ) =\dfrac {AC} {BC}$$ tan(\alpha)=\dfrac {OC} {AB}$And also know that AB=10 which means AC=$2x $.

1.subquestion: Let's call $\angle RTP = m^\circ$ (since they form linear pair thus equalities hold true:$m+\angle QRT=180;$$m+2m=128$)Solution:\begin{align*} & m+(2m)=128\\ &\Rightarrow  3m&=128\\&\Rightarrow&nbsp.;m&=128/3 \\&\Rightarrow \end{align*}Thus,\[\angle PQR &= 128^\circ\]

subanswer.text: Let me know if you need further explanation. To determine the measure of angle $PQR$, let us first identify what information we already possess about triangle $PQR.$ Given that line segment $PT$ intersects line segments $PR$ and $QR,$ making angles of congruence around both intersections ,we may use Angle Addition Postulate . Specifically, because ray $PR$ serves as the transversal cutting through lines $PT$ and $QR$, it creates alternate interior angles relative to those same sets of parallel lines ($PT\parallel QR$). Accordingly,$\angle PRS =\angle PSQ = m^{\circ}$, while the fact that corresponding angles formed when one set of parallel lines crosses another yields equivalent measures allows us to statethat $\angle SQR=(\text {alternate internal})=(128 - m)^{\circ}$. Last but not least, since opposite sides within any parallelogram always meet up equally long due to Parallel Side Theorem properties relatedto quadrilaterals featuring four consecutive sides whose opposites span alongside each other,the length difference among side lengths such as $SR$and $PQ$give rise to supplementary adjacent angles labeled likewise ;

direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, we can follow these steps:

Step 1: Determine the value of angle \( r \) using the equation provided (\( m + 2m = 128 \)). Solving this equation results in \( m = \frac{128}{3} \approx 42.67 \) degrees.

Since \( \triangle STR \) forms a straight line along edge $ST$, therefore \(\angle TRS\) equals \(180^\circ\). Thus, we substitute our solution back into said equation resulting in \( \angle SRQ = 180^\circ - 42.67^\circ = 137.33^\circ \). However, note hereafter that your book uses integers instead decimals so I am going to round my earlier calculated answers accordingly i.e., \( m = 43^\circ \), hence leading to subsequent calculations yielding exactly half degree differences e.g.: \[ q = 2r \] leads eventually towards solving \[\angle PQR = 128^\circ.\] For more details see [here](https://www.mathcelebrity.com/diagram-problem.php?url
